title: Enacts "personalized gun safety provisions" to establish safety standards and ensure that firearms can only be fired by authorized users
summary: Enacts personalized gun safety provisions creating a temporary state commission to adopt standards for firearms sold or manufactured in this state (and test prototypes) including, but not limited to, personalizing all firearms manufactured, assembled, altered, offered for sale, sold, traded, transferred, shipped, leased, distributed, acquired or possessed within the state so that only authorized users can operate them; requires manufacturers and others to comply with the standard four years from the date on which the commission's original standard is adopted; exempts antique firearms and those manufactured prior to the compliance date, except that dealers are prohibited from selling or otherwise transferring those guns; imposes penalties against those who manufacture, transport or ship firearms that do not meet the safety standard and against those who deface or alter the personalized characteristic; authorizes persons who are injured, or the representative of those killed, by the discharge of firearms not meeting the standard to bring an action against the person who fires the weapon and the owner thereof.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2078

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the penal law, in relation to personalized gun safety

PURPOSE OF THE BILL:
To reduce the incidence of
deaths and injuries
attributable to guns through design changes by creating a
personalized gun standard. Personalized firearms can also reduce the
flow of stolen guns which are frequently used to commit crimes.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
The bill amends the penal law by adding a new article 401
"Personalized Gun Safety Act." A temporary firearm safety
standard commission,
consisting of nine members including the superintendent of state
police, the commissioner of the division of criminal justice services
and the commissioner of health, is created for the purpose of
establishing a personalized safety performance standard for firearms.
Such standard will require that all firearms manufactured, assembled,
altered, offered for sale, sold, traded, transferred, shipped,
leased, distributed, acquired or possessed within the state shall be
"personalized" so that only authorized users can operate them.
The commission shall formulate the necessary testing procedure to
determine if a firearm complies with the standard and shall designate
one or more independent laboratories for determining whether firearms
comply with the standard. The manufacturer of a firearm must submit a
prototype of the firearm model for testing to one of the independent
laboratories designated by the commission. If the firearm model fails
to meet the safety standard, the firearm cannot be manufactured or
offered for sale until the firearm has been modified to meet the
standard and has passed the test on resubmission. If the firearm
meets the standard, the Superintendent of state police shall issue a
certificate stating that the firearm model meets the standard. The
certified label shall be imprinted on the approved firearm.

Manufacturers and others are required to comply with the standard four
years from the date on which the commission's original standard is
adopted. This time period acknowledges the gun manufacturers' need
for time to research the technology and to retool. Antique firearms
are exempt from the requirements because they are typically purchased
and kept as collector's items and not for use. Firearms manufactured
prior to the compliance date are also exempt. However, dealers are
prohibited from selling or otherwise transferring those guns.

This prohibition is intended to prevent dealers and others from
stockpiling guns that do not comply with the safety standard. Law
enforcement and military personnel are also exempt from the
requirements of the law.

In addition to the standard penalties against those who manufacture,
transport or ship firearms that do not meet the safety standard and
against those who deface or alter the personalized characteristics of
a firearm, the bill enables individuals who are injured or the
representative of those killed by the discharge of firearms not
meeting the standard to bring an action against the person who fires
the weapon and the owner. The bill does recognize the defense that
the firearm was being used by a law enforcement officer in the line
of duty or for self protection.

JUSTIFICATION:
There are approximately 40,000 gun
deaths in the United
States annually. Some 1,400 youngsters commit suicide with guns
annually. In 1994, according to the NYS Department of Health, there
were over 700 cases of hospitalization and over 300 deaths involving
children due to firearms. In 1994, there were nearly 4,000
hospitalizations due to firearm injuries and more than 2,000 deaths
as a result of firearm injuries. Deaths and injuries from firearms
are a major public health problem. Various strategies to reduce the
number of these tragedies have been proposed. These approaches
primarily focus on the behavior of the individual, as opposed to the
design of the firearm itself. Injury prevention professionals tend to
advocate for the modification of the design of products rather than
behavior modification as an effective way to prevent injury and
death. Thus, many products including drug packages, cigarette
lighters and motor vehicles have been modified to make them safer.

Changing the design of firearms so that they are personalized can also
reduce the likelihood of certain gun-related deaths and injuries.
Personalized or "smart" guns, which can only be fired by the
authorized user, would be inoperable by the young child, the
depressed contemplating suicide, and the criminal who steals a firearm.

While many young children are victims of unintentional shootings,
teenagers are at even greater risk of dying from an unintentional
gunshot wound. However, should a youngster find a personalized
firearm, it would be inoperable regardless of the child's behavior
thereby preventing many deaths and injuries.

Studies have shown that 40 percent to 70 percent of the guns used by
felons are stolen, most from private homes. Since thefts, which total
some half-million guns a year, are a significant source of guns used
in crime, requiring all guns to be personalized could limit the
availability of firearms to adults and juveniles in the illegal or
secondary gun market.

A variety of technologically feasible designs can be incorporated into
a firearm to personalize it. Magnetic devices, radio frequency
transponders, and/or combination locks are just some of the designs
which will prevent an unauthorized user from firing the weapon.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
First day of November.
